answers: Palestine statehood [accept anything pro-Palestine; prompt on anything anti-Israeli]
parts: Name this African leader. He was overthrown after he tried to annex Kagera from Tanzania under Julius Nyerere.
Amin’s fantasies involved marrying this current monarch. Colonies that gained their independence under this monarch included Uganda, Kenya, and Ghana, which was formerly known as the Gold Coast.
Amin hosted terrorists supporting this cause, who were attacked during Operation Thunderbolt. Terrorists supporting this cause threw a wheelchair-ridden 81-year old off the Achille Lauro.

Name these concepts that are initially outlined within a three-tiered hierarchy ranging from spirits to souls to entelechies. In that work, these “windowless” simple substances represent the real component of matter.
Monads were central to the philosophy of this thinker who also formulated the identity of indiscernibles and is credited with co-developing calculus independent of Isaac Newton.

Despite popularizing the term, Leibniz was not the first philosopher to discuss monads. Leibniz actually borrowed the term from The Principles of the Most Ancient and Modern Philosophy, the best-known book by this philosopher who was herself educated largely through letters with fellow Cambridge Platonist, Henry More.

answers: management [accept word forms such as managers; prompt on more general answers like boss or supervisors]
parts: Name this corporate role, whose tasks are contrasted with leadership and which involves organizing employees and resources. The scientific form of this role was developed at the Bethlehem Steel Mills.

In The Principles of Scientific Management, this engineer argued against the use of "rule of thumb" principles. This leader of the Efficiency Movement is also known as the father of industrial engineering.

This management theorist and business consultant created the management by objectives model and emphasized the importance of self control in books such as The Effective Executive and Managing Oneself.

answers: Mia Couto [accept António Emílio Leite Couto]
parts: Name this author. Tuahira and Muidinga discover Kindzu’s notebooks while hiding in an abandoned bus in this author’s novel Sleepwalking Land.
Couto writes in this language, for which he won the Camões Prize in 2013. Camões wrote The Lusiads in this Iberian language.

Portuguese author António Lobo Antunes wrote of his time in Angola working in this profession. The only character who doesn’t go blind in Jose Saramago’s Blindness is the wife of a member of this profession.

answers: adherens junctions [accept zonula adherens or spot adherens junctions or intermediate junctions or “belt desmosome”; prompt on ZA; do not accept or prompt on “desmosome” alone]
parts: Name these cellular junctions whose function is mediated by complexes of cadherin and catenin. These junctions are characteristically enriched in phospho-tyrosine epitopes.

The adhesive properties of adherens junctions largely result from interactions between this cytoskeletal protein and the complex of bound cadherins. This protein’s beta-form is a common loading control in Western blots.

Epithelium development in Drosophila is unique for beginning at the 14th cleavage cycle, since the first 13 nuclear divisions occur without this process. Normally, this process occurs alongside telophase and divides the cytoplasm among the two daughter cells.

answers: timbales [accept pailas or timbales latines; prompt on drums]
parts: Name this metal-cased, single-headed drum popular in mambo music and Afro-Cuban jazz. Tito Puente is regarded as the “King of” this instrument, which can readily be heard on his song “Oye como va”.

The influences of mambo rhythms and Afro-Cuban jazz inspired this Jazz trumpeter to write the early Latin Jazz standard “Manteca”. He is known for performing with a bent trumpet and characteristically puffed out cheeks.

The later Latin jazz style of bossa nova was heavily popularized in the US by the recordings of this jazz saxophonist who recorded “The Girl from Ipanema” for an album co-named for Brazilian guitarist João Gilberto.

Gustavo Dudamel, the celebrated conductor of the L.A. Philharmonic, has worked globally to create musical projects based on this program created by the Venezuelan educator José Abreu. This program’s goal is to provide music education to poor and vulnerable children.

Conductor Serge Koussevitzky commissioned many new works, including concertos for this instrument by Copland and Ravel. Ravel also wrote a concerto for this instrument to be performed by Paul Wittgenstein with only the left hand.

Serge Koussevitsky was the longtime leader of this city’s Symphony Orchestra, which along with orchestras in New York, Philadelphia, Chicago, and Cleveland, comprise the “Big Five” orchestras of the U.S. This city’s Symphony Orchestra spends its summers at the Tanglewood Music Festival.

answers: Kurt Gödel [accept Gödel metric or Gödel solution or Gödel universe]
parts: Name this quantity. This quantity provides the first term in a model of the Big Bang theory centering on the presence of cold dark matter.
This German physicist originally referred to the cosmological constant as his “biggest blunder” when he included that constant in his namesake field equations.

This other scientist’s namesake metric is an exact solution to the Einstein field equations for a swirling dust cloud in which the stress-energy tensor contains two terms, one for matter density and one a nonzero value of lambda.

answers: the end of the world [answer equivalents like the apocalypse]
parts: Name this event. A Czesław Miłosz (“CHESS-waff mee-WOHSH”) poem that ends with a “white-haired old man” saying “there will be no other” occurrence of this event is titled for a “song on” it.
Czesław Miłosz is an author from this country. Wisława Szymborska (“vis-WAH-vah shim-BOR-skah”) wrote poetry in its city of Kraków.
This author’s poem “Out of the World” is dedicated to the memory of Miłosz. This man wrote “By God, the old man could handle a spade” in his poem “Digging.”
Name this alternative metal album that includes the songs “Invincible” and “Pneuma.” It was its band’s first album since the 2006 release of 10,000 Days.

One of the most infamous gaps between rock albums was between this band's 1993 album The Spaghetti Incident and their 2008 album Chinese Democracy. This Axl Rose-fronted band recorded the song "Welcome to the Jungle."

Fans of this band have been waiting for a new album since the 2005 release of Hypnotize and Mesmerize. Serj Tankian is the lead singer of this band whose biggest hit begins “Wake up / Grab a brush and put a little makeup.”

answers: Gustavus Adolphus [or Gustav II Adolf; or Gustavus Adolphus the Great; prompt on Gustav or Gustavus]
parts: Name this king. This king’s death came after he entered the 1632 Battle of Lutzen with no protection, claiming “the Lord God is my armor!”.
Gustavus Adolphus led this country into the Thirty Years’ War while head of its royal house of Vasa.
Engelbrekt Engelbrektsson led a group of miners of this material in rebellion against Eric of Pomerania. Sweden produced much of Europe’s supply of this material at the Falun Mine.
Name this practice of taking multiple wives, which is restricted to four women by the Quran.

Wadud is also known for controversially claiming that women can hold this role when serving mixed sex congregations. In Zaidi Islam, the holder of this title has historically been equivalent to the King of Yemen.

Another Muslim feminist, Asra Nomani, dedicated her "Islamic Bill of Rights for Women in the Mosque" to this figure. According to the Stories of the Prophets, this figure was the daughter of the King of Maghreb and was later made into the mistress of the Pharaoh's harem.

answers: George [accept George III or George IV]
abolition of slavery [accept anything indicating anti-slavery]
parts: Name this person, who was depicted alongside her husband in enormous green bags in a famous cartoon. This person’s relationship with Bartolomeo Pergami was the subject of a scandalous 19th century trial.
Caroline was the wife of an extremely obese king of this name. That king’s father of the same name was denounced for “repeated injuries and usurpations” in a 1776 document.
In her quarrel with George, Caroline allied with Henry Brougham, a supporter of this cause. This cause was supported by William Wilberforce and Josiah Wedgwood.

answers: liquids [accept Stockmayer liquid or Luttinger liquid]
gels [accept gelation; accept any specific type of gel, such as hydrogels, aerogels, etc.; prompt on colloid, dispersion or emulsion]
parts: Stockmayer names a theory of these substances in which they are modelled as a collection of spheres with embedded point dipoles at their centers. Electrons in a 1-dimensional conductor act as one of these substances in a separate model created by J.M. Luttinger.

Stockmayer liquids are modelled mathematically by a potential that is a specific case of this other potential from computational chemistry, which includes a 6th power attractive and 12th power repulsive term.

With Paul Flory, Stockmayer names a modification of the Carothers equation describing the formation of one of these substances from a step-growth polymer. Agarose is a commonly used example of these substances in labs.

answers: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings
Henderson [accept Annie Henderson, Eugene Henderson, or Henderson the Rain King]
parts: Name this book whose narrator experiences racism and a teenage pregnancy in the town of Stamps, Arkansas. It takes its title from Paul Laurence Dunbar’s poem “Sympathy.”

I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings was written after Maya Angelou accepted a bet that she couldn’t write this type of book “as literature.” Books of this type are accounts of a person’s life written by that person.

The character of “Momma,” who is actually Maya’s grandmother, has this last name. This surname belongs to a fictional millionaire who encounters the Arnewi and Wariri tribes in Africa before returning to America to become a doctor.

answers: Walter Mondale [or Walter Frederick Mondale; accept Fritz Mondale]
parts: Name this senator who died in a 2002 plane crash days before an election against Norm Coleman. This senator’s televised funeral also featured a giant beach ball bouncing around the Williams Arena.
Wellstone was a member of this state’s Democratic-Farmer-Labor party. Norm Coleman was later defeated in a Senate race by Al Franken in this state.

Wellstone was replaced on the Democratic-Farmer-Labor ticket by this former presidential candidate. He lost in a landslide to Reagan in 1984 after using the slogan “where’s the beef?” to win the primaries.

answers: “Why is a raven like a writing desk?” [answers must contain the words raven and desk and must indicate a similarity between the two]
parts: Name this absurd riddle posed to Alice by the Mad Hatter during a tea party in Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland. The exact phrasing is not necessary.
The Exeter Book contains numerous Anglo-Saxon riddles written in this medieval language, which evolved into a modern language. It was used to write Beowulf.
A traditional English riddle begins “As I was going to [this place] / Upon the road I met seven wives” who each had seven sacks, with each sack having seven cats, and each cat having seven kits.

answers: Arcadia [accept Et in Arcadia Ego] (The second painting is Poussin’s version)
Rome [do not accept or prompt on “the Vatican” or “Vatican City”]
parts: Name this pastoral location. This location was depicted in a separate “memento mori” painting in which four idealized peasants place their hands on a tomb containing the title phrase.

The aforementioned darker depiction of Arcadia was created by this Italian Baroque artist. The two shepherds in this artist’s version of that scene are also present in that work’s companion piece, The Flaying of Marsyas.
Guercino’s copy of Et In Arcadia Ego can be found in this Italian city, where it is on display at the Palazzo Barberini. This city also houses the Borghese Gallery and the Pantheon.

answers: resonance [or Lindblad resonance or Kozai resonance]
parts: Name this group of minor planets whose namesake member is a centaur, which like the other members of this group, possesses a long-period, eccentric orbit but lacks evidence of a comet tail.

The Damocloids are believed to be nuclei from a family of comets, which have outgassed and gone dormant. That family is named for this comet, which has a roughly 75-year orbit and is named for an English astronomer.

The Tisserand parameter can also be used to describe stellar 3-body systems in which perturbations cause a form of this phenomenon to occur between orbital inclination and eccentricity. Another form of this phenomenon can drive spiral density wave formation and was discovered by Lindblad.

answers: people in poverty [accept obvious equivalents such as poor people; anti-prompt on people who are homeless]
parts: Name this condition, for which Richmond developed social casework. In the book Nickel and Dimed, Barbara Erhenreich describes living conditions for people with this condition.

Much of Richmond's work espoused this perspective of social welfare, which focuses on the resources available to people in need, instead of the problems that they face. This sort of perspective is often contrasted with a deficit perspective.
Mary Ellen Richmond is sometimes contrasted with fellow early social worker Jane Addams. With Ellen Gates Starr, Addams would go on to found this settlement house in Chicago.
